properties.DESCRIPTION: Tidal marsh grasses have been moving up the ditches over the past five years.
Since 1985, this point has become a "ghost forest," with dead pine and cedar trunks.

This dammed-up section of an unnamed tributary of Nickawampus Creek has shifted from fresh-brackish in the 1980s to salt-brackish in the 2000s as water levels increasingly elevated to the point where they began entering through the dam's water outfall on a more consistent basis.

This area has experienced the gradual decline of a stand of seven mature loblolly pines due to rising water levels and saltwater intrusion. In 1987, there were five remaining; in 1998 three remained, and in 2011 all were dead.
Vegetative species are changing in this area as marshmallows are no longer present and marsh grass and pines are disappearing due to increasing brackish water.
At Holden Creek branch, stumps show at low tide indicating the old tree line that has been inundated by rising water levels.
Previously there was a stand of locust trees here which were used as a point of reference by boaters. A combination of erosion and saltwater intrusion has claimed all of the locust trees.
The woods are moving back from all the creeks in this area.
The woods are moving back from all the creeks in this area.
The woods are moving back from all the creeks in this area.
Pumpkin Island, in 1997, the myrtle and cedar bushes were so thick you could hardly walk through them, By 2013, there was nothing left of those plants except their dead poles.
The harbor was dredged in the 1930s, and the dredge material was piled on the island in a marsh, creating a forest theref. This kept the island from eroding as much as it would have without the fill.
The spoil site next to the harbor is now becoming a shallow pond perhaps from compression or subsidence.
This area was a homestead in the early 20th century.
Assawoman Creek was deep enough in the 1800s that a boat could get all the way up to Atlantic Road.
There was once a boatyward located on Atlantic Road that built log canoes in the 1800s.

Back in the 1980s, you could not see the water on either side when traveling on Route 13 south of the CBBT toll booths because of the thick vegetation. Now it is almost wide open, and the bayside has seen erosion that moved the shoreline closer to the highway.
The trees here are dying  because the Nature Conservancy took out a farm dike allowing salt water to flow back into the farm. The area has now turned to marsh. Many cedar trees have died since 1999.
Since 1990, about half of the forest on the southeastern side of Bell's Neck has become a "ghost forest."
Previously a fresh-water marsh, this area has changed over to salt water species since 1990.
This area has seen marsh dieoff since 2008.
Marsh dieoff started in early 2000s and continues to the present time.
Over the past fifteen years, the marsh at the northern terminus of Kegotank Bay has been dying off.
Cattle were grazed here on Spartina Patens (marsh hay). It is a marsh now.
Cattle grazed here on Spartina Patens (marsh hay) up until the mid-twentieth century. This is marsh now.
The area here was once referred to as Piney Hummock. It no longer exists as such and is now a marsh.

In order to hold back rising water levels, dikes were constructed along the woods here in the early 20th century in order to protect the area so that strawberries could be grown. The dikes now define the marsh, and the woods are dying back.
In the 1930s, this area was used to raise strawberries by Bradford Hall. It is marsh now.
The marsh over which the causeway passes was once high but is now reverting to mud flats.
